DOCNAME: VRANISKOSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA" (No. 1)
JUDGES: Ganna Yudkivska;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant was appointed as a bishop ( Епархиски Архиереј на Повардарската Епархија ) in ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) . By a decision of DATE , he designated the monastery PERSON in PERSON as his residence . However , he has resided and worked in the ORG and PERSON building ( PERSON the Eparchy building ” ) .

At a press conference on DATE the applicant stated that he would join ORG . On DATE considerable number of people ( according to the Government CARDINAL and according to the applicant , CARDINAL people ) gathered at the main square in ORG protesting against his decision and requesting his dismissal from the ORG . By a decision of DATE , which was made public through the media , ORG ( Светиот PERSON ) invited the applicant to reunite with ORG within DATE . When he refused , on DATE another public protest was organised at the main square in the city of GPE .

At an extraordinary meeting of DATE , ORG , by unanimous decision , dismissed the applicant from his office on the ground that , by his unilateral accession to ORG , he had violated the oath ( NORP исповедание/ заклетва ) by which he had bound himself to safeguard the ORG ’s unity and LAW . It designated the monastery PERSON in PERSON ( “ the monastery ” ) as his new place of residence and work . It further invited the applicant to reunite with the ORG within DATE , failing which other measures would be taken in accordance with its rules . It was also decided that ORG would run the PERSON building with effect from DATE ( “ the dismissal decision ” ) .
By a decision of DATE , a ORG ( “ the Commission ” ) was set up to take the PERSON building , furniture and funds from the applicant . The media were also informed about the above decisions .
On DATE the ORG requested ORG ( “ the NORP ” ) to assist with the implementation of its decisions . The request stated , inter alia :

“ ... Due to the possible obstruction of the enforcement of this decision by the Archbishop PERSON [ the applicant ] or someone else , we request the ORG office of ORG to take any necessary measures for its implementation ... ”

On DATE police officers were deployed around the Eparchy building . At TIME , representatives of the Commission ( “ the archbishops ” , владици ) arrived in order to hand over the dismissal decision to the applicant and to take the PERSON building . They were greeted by a group of people that have gathered in front of the entrance . The door of the PERSON building was locked . The archbishops waited for the applicant and the other staff , who were at that moment inside the PERSON building , to open the door . In the meantime , the number of people gathered in front of the PERSON building increased considerably . Due to the increased tension and indications of security risks for the public order , the life and health of the applicant and other personnel in the PERSON building , ORG sent a group of QUANTITY police officers . After TIME , the archbishops took measures to break in the Eparchy building . In this connection they instructed a locksmith to break the lock . In view of the security risks , several police officers , with the consent of the archbishops , entered the Eparchy building . After having entered , the archbishops discussed with the applicant . The police secured the Eparchy building in order to prevent the crowd from breaking in . The police assessed the situation as critical and advised the applicant that his further stay in the Eparchy building , without protection , would not be safe . In such circumstances , the applicant agreed to leave by the back door . Then , the applicant and the personnel got into a car of the ORG and escorted by the police went to the monastery .

The Government submitted a DVD containing video and audio material ( CARDINAL , QUANTITY . ) regarding the applicant ’s eviction . According to it , when the archbishops arrived on the scene , there were people gathered in front of the PERSON building and media representatives . At that moment , no policeman could be seen . Then a locksmith opened the door . According to an explanation given by a journalist , the lock was broken on the request of CARDINAL of the archbishops . After TIME waiting , the archbishops entered the Eparchy building first . After TIME , the applicant left the Eparchy building with a car of the ORG . At that moment , several policemen can be seen making a passage for the applicant ’s car to leave the scene . At that moment , many more people were gathered in front of the Eparchy building .

The applicant contested the ORG ’s version of events . He referred to the facts as established by the first - instance court in the civil proceedings described below , which the ORG had not contested at that time . He argued in particular that the police had accompanied the archbishops on their arrival in the PERSON building and that the locksmith had arrived with a car secured by the police .

In DATE the applicant , who was represented by counsel , brought a civil action against the ORG and the Ministry for interference with and deprivation of possession ( смеќавање на владение ) of the PERSON building . He also sought restoration in the previous state ( воспоставување на владетелска состојба каква што била во моментот на смеќевањето и одземањето на владението ) . He claimed that at TIME on DATE ORG had interfered with his right of peaceful enjoyment of the Eparchy building which had also served as his home . He alleged that CARDINAL fully - equipped police officers had broken the lock , with the assistance of a locksmith , and entered the building , despite the fact that there had been no decision of a State body authorising the police forcibly to enforce the dismissal decision . After the break - in , PERSON , the archbishops , had served the dismissal decision on him , with which he had refused to comply . He further alleged that he had been searched and insulted by police officers . He requested that the court take oral evidence from him , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , personnel in the PERSON building who had eye - witnessed the event , Mr T. and Mr A.
The applicant based his claim , inter alia , on Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW ( see “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” below ) .

The ORG replied , inter alia , that it had acted on the ORG ’s request to enforce the dismissal decision with the aim of securing the place and preventing the disorder which had reasonably been expected to occur . Its purpose had been to protect not only the personal safety and property of the persons who had gathered , but those of the applicant as well .

On DATE ORG of ORG , relying on section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the ORG and other LAW ( “ LAW ” ) , dismissed the applicant ’s claim . Relying inter alia on the statements given by the applicant , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON it established the following : that the PERSON building had been the applicant ’s permanent residence , namely , that the upper floor had served as a place of residence for him and the other personnel and that the working premises of the PERSON had been on the lower floor ; that at TIME on DATE , media representatives and a group of people had gathered in front of the Eparchy building . As the applicant and other members of the staff had refused to open the door , the police , assisted by a locksmith , had broken in and searched the applicant , staff and LOC . The applicant had had a discussion with the archbishops and after he had refused to cooperate , the police coordinator had ordered the applicant and the personnel to leave the PERSON building by the back door . The applicant and the personnel had then got into a car and , escorted by the police , gone to the monastery .
The court held that :

“ ... it is undisputed that the plaintiff [ the applicant ] had possession of the Povardarska Eparchy , which had served not only as the plaintiff ’s [ the applicant ’s ] place of work for his duties as a bishop , but also as his home ... having regard to the anticipated obstruction by the plaintiff [ applicant ] or others and on the basis of the decision of DATE , the President of ORG requested [ the Ministry ] to enforce its decision ... As the plaintiff [ the applicant ] had refused to [ repudiate his previous conduct ] , it appears that ORG anticipated doubts concerning enforcement of the decision and the request for police intervention were reasonable ... The plaintiff [ the applicant ] and the personnel were taken out by the back door of the Eparchy building in order to avoid any contact with the people and any possible assault ... ”

The applicant appealed on the grounds , inter alia , that the lower court had dismissed his claim despite having established that he had had possession of the PERSON building , which had also served as his place of residence , and that that possession had been forcibly appropriated by the police . He complained that the court had wrongly applied section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as the ORG ’s decision could not be considered “ a decision of another body given in accordance with law ” . He also complained that ORG had acted as an executive body of the ORG by enforcing the dismissal decision with the use of force . He again invoked Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal , finding it undisputed that ORG had acted at the ORG ’s request .
On the facts established by the first - instance court , it held that the latter ’s decision should have been based on CARDINAL and not section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW . ORG found that :

“ ... the plaintiff [ the applicant ] had only occupied ( детенција ) the apartment situated in the PERSON building on the basis of his position as a bishop . His dismissal from this position and the assignment by ORG monastery as his permanent place of residence and work entailed the loss of that occupancy . As the plaintiff [ the applicant ] did not have possession within the meaning of section CARDINAL of the Act , he could not claim protection of the possession under section CARDINAL of the Act . ”
“ Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL
... ORG , as well as ORG in GPE , ORG , ORG , ORG and other religious communities and groups are separate from the ORG and equal before the law .
Article CARDINAL
The inviolability of the home is guaranteed .
The right to the inviolability of the home may be restricted only by a court decision for the investigation or prevention of criminal offences or protection of people ’s health .
Article CARDINAL
Every citizen may invoke protection of the freedoms and rights set forth in the LAW before the courts , including before ORG , in proceedings based on the principles of priority and urgency ... ”

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW provide that a property owner can bring a civil claim for restitution against the occupier ( држателот ) of an individually specified property . The owner has to prove that he or she has title to the property of which restitution is claimed and that the defendant has actual control of that property .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides , inter alia , that anyone who has control of property , either directly or through a representative , can claim to have possession ( владение ) of it .

Under LAW of the LAW , a person who , on the basis of a post of employment or a similar relationship , or as a member of a household , makes use of a property on the basis of another ’s order or executes another ’s decision without acquiring any personal advantage can not be regarded as having possession ( владение ) , as he or she is a mere occupier ( прост држател или детентор ) .

Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , no one has a right unlawfully ( неовластено ) to disturb ( смеќава ) and deprive ( одзема ) the possession even if he or she considers having stronger right of possession . Under sub - section CARDINAL of the LAW , it is not considered an unlawful disturbance of possession if the disturbance or deprivation is authorised by law or by a decision of a court or other body taken in accordance with a law which provides for such disturbance or deprivation .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides that a person in possession ( владетелот ) of a property or a holder of a proprietary right is entitled to protect his or her possession from disturbance or seizure .

Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides that a person whose possession has been unlawfully disturbed or seized is entitled to request the court to establish that the disturbance or seizure has taken place , to order reinstatement and proscribe any further or similar actions . Court protection is available in special proceedings in accordance with the most recent peaceful possession , regardless of the conduct of the person in possession and whether the disturbance was lawful and in the public interest .
Section CARDINAL of LAW defines different grounds for claiming civil compensation .

Under section CARDINAL , in the event that a human right or freedom is violated , the court may award just satisfaction regardless of whether or not compensation for pecuniary damage has been awarded .

Section CARDINAL of LAW provides that criminal proceedings must be instituted at the request of an authorised prosecutor . In cases involving offences subject to ex officio prosecution by the ORG or on an application by the injured party , the authorised prosecutor is the public prosecutor , whereas in cases involving offences for which only private charges may be brought , the authorised prosecutor is the private prosecutor . If the public prosecutor finds no grounds for the institution or continuation of criminal proceedings , his role may be assumed by the injured party acting as a subsidiary prosecutor under the conditions specified in LAW .

Section CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that where the public prosecutor finds that there are no grounds for prosecuting an offence subject to ex officio prosecution , he shall notify the injured party of his decision within DATE . He shall also inform the injured party that he is entitled to conduct the prosecution himself . The latter may take over or continue the prosecution within DATE .
Under section CARDINAL , everyone can report a criminal offence subject to ex officio prosecution . The complaint is submitted to the public prosecutor , orally or in written .

Article QUANTITY CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provide , inter alia , that anyone who enters another ’s home without authorisation is liable to a fine or to a DATE prison sentence . If the offence is committed by an official in the performance of his or her duties , he or she is liable to a term of imprisonment of DATE . An attempt to commit the offence is also punishable .

Rule CARDINAL of the Rules of the Ministry sets out measures which the ORG ’s officials can take in discharging their duties . Under sub - heading CARDINAL , ORG officials can enter a person ’s home or other LOC after having shown an identity card and a court decision or order .

The Government submitted final decisions in which the national courts had convicted the defendants under LAW of breaching the inviolability of the victim ’s home . In those cases the courts had decided on the basis of private criminal complaints brought by the victims ( K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; ORG ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; ORG ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; DATE ; K.br.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; and PERSON ) .

In the case ORG of DATE a trial court convicted a bailiff under LAW of unauthorised entry of the victim ’s home in order to deliver a court summons . The bailiff was subject to ex officio prosecution by the public prosecutor .
